sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p:
Why there 'tis now. Sure I ſhall be out of your Clutches one Day.—Well, Guardian, I ſay no more; but if you be not as errant a Cuckold, as e'er drove Bargain upon
the Exchange, or paid Attendance to a Court, I am the Son of a Whetſtone; and ſo your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: Don't forget the Meſſage; Ha, ha,

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: I am ſo provok'd!—'tis well he's gone.

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: Oh mind him not, Gardee, but let's ſign Articles, and then—

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: And then—Adod, I believe I am Metamorphos'd; my Pulſe beats high, and my Blood boils, methinks— (Kiſſing and Hugging her.

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: Oh fye, Gardee, be not ſo violent; Conſider the Market laſts all the Year—Well, I'll in and ſee if the Lawyer be come, you'll follow.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Ay, to the World's End, my Dear. Well, Frank, thou art a lucky Fellow in thy old Age, to have ſuch a delicate Morſel, and Thirty Thouſand Pound in love with thee; I ſhall be the Envy of Batchelors, the Glory of Marry'd Men, and the Wonder of the Town. Some Guardians wou'd be glad to compound for part of the Eſtate, at diſpatching an Heireſs, but I engroſs the whole: O! Mihi praeteritos referet ſi Jupiter Annos.

head.hi: SCENE Changes to a Tavern; diſcovers Sir George and Charles with Wine before them, and Whiſper waiting.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Nay, prithee don't be Grave, Charles; Misfortunes will happen, Ha, ha, ha, 'tis ſome Comfort to have a Companion in our Sufferings.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: I am only apprehenſive for Iſabinda, her Father's Humour is implacable; and how far his Jealouſie may tranſport him to her Undoing, ſhocks my Soul to think.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: But ſince you eſcap'd undiſcover'd by him, his Rage will quickly laſh into a Calm, never fear it.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
But who knows what that unlucky Dog, Marplot, told him; nor can I Imagine what brought him hither; that Fellow is ever doing Miſchief; and yet, to give him his due, he never deſigns it. This is ſome Blundering Adventure,
wherein he thought to ſhew his Friendſhip, as he calls it: A Curſe on him.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Then you muſt forgive him; what ſaid he?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Said! nay, I had more mind to cut his Throat, than hear his Excuſes.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Whiſp.
sp.p: Sir, I ſaw him go into Sir Francis Gripe's juſt now.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Oh! then he is upon your Buſineſs, Sir George; a thouſand to one but he makes ſome Miſtake there too.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Impoſſible, without he huffs the Lady, and makes Love to Sir Francis.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Mr. Marplot is below, Gentlemen, and deſires to know if he may have Leave to wait upon ye.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: How civil the Rogue is when he has done a fault!

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Ho! Deſire him to walk up. Prithee, Charles, throw off this Chagreen, and be good Company.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Nay, hang him, I'm not angry with him. Whiſper, fetch me Pen, Ink, and Paper.

sp.speaker: Whiſp.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Do but mark his ſheepiſh Look, Sir George.

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: Dear Charles, don't o'rwhelm a Man—already under inſupportable Affliction. I'm ſure I always intend to ſerve my Friends; but if my malicious Stars deny the Happineſs, is the fault mine?

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Never mind him, Mr. Marplot; he is eat up with Spleen. But tell me, what ſays Miranda?

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: Says—nay, we are all undone there too.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: I told you ſo; nothing proſpers that he undertakes.

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: Why can I help her having choſe your Father for Better for Worſe?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: So: There's another of Fortune's ſtrokes. I ſuppoſe I ſhall be edg'd out of my Eſtate with Twins every Year, let who will get 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: What is the Woman really poſſeſt?

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: Yes with the Spirit of Contradiction, ſhe rail'd at you moſt prodigiouſly.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: That's no ill Sign.

div.stage: Enter Whiſper, with Pen, Ink and Paper.

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: You'd ſay it was no good Sign, if you knew all.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Why prithee?

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: Hark'e, Sir George, Let me warn you, purſue your old Haunt no more, it may be dangerous.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: My old Haunt, what d'you mean?

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: Why in ſhort then, ſince you will have it, Miranda vows if you dare approach the Garden-Gate at Eight a Clock, as you us'd, you ſhall be ſaluted with a Blunderbuſs, Sir. Theſe were her Words; nay, ſhe bid me tell you ſo too.

sp.speaker: Sir George,
sp.p: Ha! The Garden-Gate at Eight, as I us'd to do! There muſt be a Meaning in this. Is there ſuch a Gate, Charles?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Yes, yes; it opens into the Park, I ſuppoſe her Ladyſhip has made many a ſcamper through it.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: It muſt be an Aſſignation then. Ha, my Heart ſprings with Joy, 'tis a propitious Omen. My dear Marplot, let me embrace thee, thou art my Friend, my better Angel—

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: What do you mean, Sir George?

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: No matter what I mean. Here take a Bumper to the Garden-Gate, ye dear Rogue, you.

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: You have Reaſon to be tranſported, Sir George; I have ſav'd your Life.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: My Life! thou haſt ſav'd my Soul, Man. Charles, if thou do'ſt not pledge this Health, may'ſt thou never taſte the Joys of Love.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Whiſper, be ſure you take care how you deliver this (gives him the Letter) bring me the Anſwer to my Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Whiſp.
sp.p: I warrant you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: Whither does that Letter go?—Now dare I not ask for my Blood.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Now I'm for you.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: To the Garden-Gate at the Hour of Eight, Charles, along, Huzza!

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: I begin to conceive you.

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: That's more than I do, Egad—to the Garden-Gate, Huzza, (Drinks.) But I hope you deſign to keep far enough off on't, Sir George.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Ay, ay, never fear that; ſhe ſhall ſee I deſpiſe her Frowns, let her uſe her Blunderbuſs againſt the next Fool, ſhe ſhan't reach me with the Smoak, I warrant her, Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: Ah, Charles, if you cou'd receive a Diſappointment thus En Cavalier, one ſhou'd have ſome comfort in being beat for you.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: The Fool comprehends nothing.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Nor wou'd I have him; prithee take him along with thee.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Enough: Marplot, you ſhall go home with me.

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: I'm glad I'm well with him however. Sir George, yours. Egad, Charles, aſking me to go home with him, gives me a ſhrewd Suſpicion there's more in the Garden-Gate than I comprehend. Faith, I'll give him the drop, and away to Guardians, and find it out.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: I kiſs both your Hands—And now for the Garden-Gate.

l.hi: It's Beauty gives the Aſſignation there,
And Love too powerful grows t' admit of Fear.

div.trailer: The End of the Third Act.

div.head: ACT the Fourth.

head.hi: SCENE the Outſide of Sir Jealous Traffick's Houſe, Patch peeping out of Door.

sp.speaker: Whiſp.
sp.p: HA, Mrs. Patch, this is a lucky Minute, to find you ſo readily, my Maſter dies with Impatience.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: My Lady imagin'd ſo, and by her Orders I have been ſcouting this Hour in ſearch of you, to inform you that Sir Jealous has invited ſome Friends to Supper with him to Night, which gives an Opportunity to your Maſter to make uſe of his Ladder of Ropes: The Cloſet Window ſhall be open, and Iſabinda ready to receive him; bid him come immediately.

sp.speaker: Whiſp.
sp.p: Excellent! He'll not diſappoint, I warrant him: But hold, I have a Letter here, which I'm to carry an Anſwer of. I can't think what Language the Direction is.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: Pho, 'tis no Language, but a Character which the Lovers invented to avert Diſcovery. Ha, I hear my old Maſter coming down Stairs, it is impoſſible you ſhou'd have an Anſwer; away, and bid him come himſelf for that—Be gone, we are ruin'd if you're ſeen, for he has doubl'd his Care ſince the laſt Accident.

sp.speaker: Whiſp.
sp.p: I go, I go.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: There go thou into my Pocket. (Puts it beſides, and it falls down.) Now I'll up the Back-Stairs, leſt I meet him. Well, a dextrous Chamber-maid is the Ladies beſt Utenſil, I ſay.

div.stage: Enter Sir Jealous with a Letter in his Hand.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p:
So, this is ſome Comfort; this tells me that Seignior Don Diego Babinetto is ſafely arriv'd; he ſhall marry my Daughter the Minute he comes, ha. What's here (takes up the Letter Patch drop'd) A Letter! I don't know what to
make of the Superſcription. I'll ſee what's within ſide, [opens it] humph; 'tis Hebrew I think. What can this mean. There muſt be ſome trick in it; this was certainly deſign'd for my Daughter, but I don't know that ſhe can ſpeak any Language but her Mother-Tongue. No matter for that, this may be one of Love's Hieroglyphicks, and I fancy I ſaw Patch's Tail ſweep by. That Wench may be a Slut, and inſtead of guarding my Honour, betray it; I'll find it out I'm reſolv'd; who's there? What anſwer did you bring from the Gentlemen I ſent you to invite?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: That they'd all wait of you, Sir, as I told you before, but I ſuppoſe you forgot, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Did I ſo, Sir, but I ſhan't forget to break your Head, if any of them come, Sir.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Come, Sir, why did you not ſend me to deſire their Company, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: But I ſend you now to deſire their Abſence; ſay I have ſomething extraordinary fallen out, which calls me abroad contrary to Expectation, and aſk their Pardon, and d'ye hear, ſend the Butler to me.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: If this Paper has a Meaning I'll find it. Lay the Cloath in my Daughter's Chamber, and bid the Cook ſend Supper thither preſently.

sp.speaker: Butl.
sp.p: Yes, Sir,—hey day, what's the Matter now?

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: He wants the Eyes of Argus, that has a young handſome Daughter in this Town, but my Comfort is, I ſhall not be troubl'd long with her. He that pretends to rule a Girl once in her Teens, had better be at Sea in a Storm, and would be in leſs Danger.

l.hi: For let him do, or Counſel all he can,
She thinks and dreams of nothing elſe but Man.

head.hi: SCENE Iſabinda's Chamber, Iſabinda and Patch.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Are you ſure, no Body ſaw you ſpeak to Whiſper?

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: Yes, very ſure Madam, but I heard Sir Jealous coming down Stairs, ſo I clapt this Letter into my Pocket. (feels for the Letter.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: A Letter! give it me quickly.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: Bleſs me! what's become on't—I'm ſure I put it— (Searching ſtill.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Is it poſſible, thou could'ſt be ſo careleſs—Oh! I'm undone for ever if it be loſt.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: I muſt have drop'd it upon the Stairs. But why are you ſo much alarm'd, if the worſt happens no body can read it, Madam, nor find out whom it was deſign'd for.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: If it falls into my Father's Hands the very Figure of a Letter will produce ill Conſequences. Run and look for it upon the Stairs this Moment.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: Nay, I'm ſure it can be no where elſe.— (As ſhe's going out of the Door meets the Butler.) How now, what do you want?

sp.speaker: Butl.
sp.p: My Maſter order'd me to lay the Cloth here for his Supper.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Ruin'd paſt Redemption— (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: You miſtake ſure; what ſhall we do?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I thought he expected Company to Night—Oh! poor Charles—Oh! unfortunate Iſabinda.

sp.speaker: Butl.
sp.p: I thought ſo too, Madam, but I ſuppoſe he has alter'd his Mind. (Lays the Cloth, and Exit.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: The Letter is the Cauſe; this heedleſs Action has undone me: Fly and faſten the Cloſet Window, which will give Charles notice to retire. Ha, my Father, oh! Confuſion.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Patch, whither are you going. I'll have no body ſtir out of the Room till after Supper.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: Sir, I was only going to reach your eaſie Chair—Oh! wretched Accident!

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: I'll have no body ſtir out of the Room. I don't want my eaſy Chair.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: What will be the event of this? (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Heark ye, Daughter; do you know this Hand?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: As I ſuſpected—Hand do you call it, Sir? 'Tis ſome School-boy's Scraul.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: Oh! Invention, thou Chamber-maids beſt Friend, aſſiſt me.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Are you ſure you don't underſtand it?
sp.stage: (Patch. Feels in her Boſom, and ſhakes her Coats.)

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Do you underſtand it, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: I wiſh I did.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Thank Heaven you do not. (Aſide.) Then I know no more of it than you do indeed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: Oh Lord, Oh Lord, what have you done, Sir? Why the Paper is mine, I drop'd it out of my Boſom. (Snatching it from him.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Ha! yours, Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: What does ſhe mean by owning it. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, it is.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: What is it? Speak,

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: Why, Sir, it is a Charm for the Tooth-ach—I have worn it this ſeven Year, 'twas given me by an Angel for ought I know, when I was raving with the Pain; for no body knew from whence he came, nor whither he went, he charg'd me never to open it, leſt ſome dire Vengeance befal me, and Heaven knows what will be the Event. Oh! cruel Misfortune that I ſhould drop it, and you ſhould open it—If you had not open'd it—

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Excellent Wench. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Pox of your Charms and Whims for me; if that be all, 'tis well enough; there, there, burn it, and I warrant you no Vengeance will follow.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: So, all's right again thus far. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p:
I would not loſe Patch for the World—I'll take courage a little. (Aſide.) Is this Uſage for your Daughter, Sir? Muſt my Virtue and Conduct be ſuſpected? For every Trifle, you immure melike ſome dire Offender here, and deny me
all Recreations which my Sex enjoy, and the Cuſtom of the Country and Modeſty allow; yet not content with that, you make my Confinement more intolerable by your Miſtruſts and Jealouſies; wou'd I were dead, ſo I were free from this. (Weeps.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: To morrow rids you of this tireſome Load,—Don Diego Babinetto will be here, and then my Care ends, and his begins.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Is he come then? Oh how ſhall I avoid this hated Marriage? (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Come will you ſit down?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I can't eat, Sir.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: No, I dare ſwear he has given her Supper enough. I wiſh I cou'd get into the Cloſet— (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Well, if you can't eat, then give me a Song whilſt I do.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I have ſuch a Cold I can ſcarce ſpeak, Sir, much leſs ſing. How ſhall I prevent Charles coming in. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: I hope you have the uſe of your Fingers, Madam. Play a Tune upon your Spinnet, whilſt your Woman ſings me a Song.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: I'm as much out of Tune as my Lady, if he knew all. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I ſhall make excellent Muſick. (Sits down to play.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: Really, Sir, I'm ſo frighted about your opening this Charm, that I can't remember one Song.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Piſh, Hang your Charm; come, come, ſing any thing.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: Yes, I'm likely to ſing truly, (Aſide) humph, humph, bleſs me, Sir, I cannot raiſe my Voice, my Heart pants ſo.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Why, what does your Heart pant ſo that you can't play neither? Pray what Key are you in, ha?

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: Ah, wou'd the Key was turn'd of you once. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Why don't you ſing, I ſay?

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: When Madam has put her Spinnet in Tune, Sir, humph, humph—

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I cannot play, Sir, whatever ails me. (Riſing.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Zounds ſit down, and play me a Tune, or I'll break the Spinnet about your Ears.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: What will become of me? (Sits down and plays.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Come Miſtreſs. (To Patch

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: Yes, Sir. (Sings, but horridly out of Tune.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Hey, hey, why you are a top of the Houſe, and you are down in the Cellar. What is the meaning of this? Is it on purpoſe to croſs me, ha?

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: Pray Madam, take it a little lower, I cannot reach that Note—nor any Note I fear.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Well, begin—Oh! Patch we ſhall be diſcover'd.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: I ſink with the Apprehenſion, Madam,—humph, humph— (Sings) (Charles pulls open the Cloſet Door.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Muſick and Singing

l.hi: 'Tis thus the bright Coeleſtial Court above,
Beguiles the Hours with Muſick and with Love.

sp.p: Death! her Father there, (The Women ſhriek) then I muſt fly—
sp.stage: (Sir Jealous riſes up haſtily, ſeeing Charles ſlip back into the Cloſet.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Hell and Furies, a Man in the Cloſet—

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: Ah! a Ghoſt, a Ghoſt—he muſt not enter the Cloſet—
sp.stage: (Iſabinda throws her ſelf down before the Cloſetdoor as in a Sound.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: The Devil! I'll make a Ghoſt of him I warrant you. (Strives to get by.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: Oh hold, Sir, have a care, you'll tread upon my Lady—who waits there? Bring ſome Water: Oh! this comes of your opening the Charm: Oh, oh, oh, oh. (Weeps aloud.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: I'll charm you, Houſe-wife, here lies the Charm, that conjur'd this Fellow in I'm ſure on't, come out you Raſcal, do ſo: Zounds take her from the Door, or I'll ſpurn her from it. and break your Neck down Stairs.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Oh, oh, where am I—He's gone, I heard him leap down. (Aſide to Patch.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: Nay, then let him enter—here, here Madam, ſmell to this; come give me your Hand; come nearer to the Window, the Air will do you good.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: I wou'd ſhe were in her Grave. Where are you, Sirrah? Villain, Robber of my Honour! I'll pull you out of your Neſt. (Goes into the Cloſet.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: You'l be miſtaken, old Gentleman, the Bird is flown.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I'm glad I have 'ſcap'd ſo well. I was almoſt dead in earneſt with the Fright.

div.stage: Re-enter Sir Jealous out of the Cloſet.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Whoever the Dog were he has eſcap'd out of the Window, for the Saſh is up. But tho' he is got out of my Reach, you are not: And firſt Mrs. Pandor, with your Charms for the Tooth-ach, get out of my Houſe, go, troop; yet hold, ſtay, I'll ſee you out of my Doors my ſelf, but I'll ſecure your Charge e'er I go.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: What do you mean, Sir? Was ſhe not a Creature of your own providing?

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: She was of the Devil's providing for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: What have I done, Sir, to merit your Diſpleaſure?

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: I don't know which of you have done it; but you ſhall both ſuffer for it, till I can diſcover whoſe Guilt it is: Go, get in there, I'll move you from this ſide of the Houſe (Puſhes Iſabinda in at the other Door, and locks it; puts the Key in his Pocket.) I'll keep the Key my ſelf: I'll try what Ghoſt will get into that Room. And now forſooth I'll wait on you down Stairs.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: Ah, my poor Lady—Down Stairs, Sir, but I won't go out, Sir, till I have look'd up my Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: If thou wer't as naked as thou wer't born, thou ſhould'ſt not ſtay to put on a Smock. Come along, I ſay; when your Miſtreſs is marry'd you ſhall have your Rags, and every thing that belongs to you; but till then— (Exit pulling her out.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: Oh! barbarous Uſage for nothing.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: There, go, and come no more within ſight of my Habitation, theſe three Days, I charge you. (Slaps the Door after her.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: Did ever any Body ſee ſuch and old Monſter!

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: Oh! Mr. Charles your Affairs and mine are in an ill Poſture.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: I am immur'd to the Frowns of Fortune: But what has befal'n thee?

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: Sir Jealous, whoſe ſuſpicious Nature's always on the Watch; nay, even whilſt one Eye ſleeps, the other keeps Sentinel; upon ſight of you, flew into ſuch a violent Paſſion, that I cou'd find no Stratagem to appeaſe him, but in ſpight of all Arguments, lock'd his Daughter into his own Apartment and turn'd me out of Doors.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Ha! oh, Iſabinda.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: And ſwears ſhe ſhall neither ſee Sun or Moon, till ſhe is Don Diego Babinetto's Wife, who arrived laſt Night, and is expected with Impatience.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: He dies, yes, by all the Wrongs of Love he ſhall; here will I plant my ſelf, and thro' my Breaſt he ſhall make his Paſſage, if he enters.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: A moſt heroick Reſolution. There might be ways found out more to your Advantage. Policy is often preferr'd to open force.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: I apprehend you not.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: What think you of perſonating this Spaniard, impoſing upon the Father, and marrying your Miſtreſs by his own Conſent.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Say'ſt thou ſo my Angel! Oh cou'd that be done, my Life to come wou'd be too ſhort to recompence thee: But how can I do that, when I neither know what Ship he came in, nor from what part of Spain; who recommends him, nor how attended.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: I can ſolve all this. He is from Madrid, his Father's Name Don Pedro Queſto Portento Babinetto. Here's a Letter of his to Sir Jealous, which he dropt one Day; you underſtand Spaniſh, and the Hand may be counterfeited: You conceive me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: My better Genius, thou haſt reviv'd my drooping Soul: I'll about it inſtantly. Come to my Lodgings, and we'll concert Matters.

head.hi: SCENE a Garden Gate open, Scentwell waiting within.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: So, this is the Gate, and moſt invitingly open: If there ſhou'd be a Blunderbuſs here now, what a dreadful Ditty wou'd my Fall make for Fools; and what a Jeſt for the Wits; how my Name wou'd be roar'd about Streets! Well I'll venture all.

sp.speaker: Scentw.
sp.p: Hiſt, hiſt, Sir George Airy—

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: A Female Voice, thus far I'am ſafe, my Dear.

sp.speaker: Scentw.
sp.p: No, I'm not your Dear, but I'll conduct you to her, give me your Hand; you muſt go thro' many a dark Paſſage and dirty Step before you arrive.—

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: I know I muſt before I arrive at Paradiſe; therefore be quick, my charming Guide.

sp.speaker: Scentw.
sp.p: For ought you know; come, come your Hand and away.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Here, here Child, you can't be half ſo ſwift as my Deſires.

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: Well let me reaſon a little with my mad ſelf. Now don't I tranſgreſs all Rules to venture upon a Man, without the Advice of the Grave and Wiſe; but then a rigid knaviſh Guardian who wou'd have marry'd me! To whom? Even to his nauſeous ſelf, or no Body. Sir George is what I have try'd in Converſation, inquir'd into his Character, am ſatisfied in both. Then his Love! Who wou'd have given a hundred Pound only to have ſeen a Woman he had not infinitely loved? So I find my liking him has furniſh'd me with Arguments enough of his ſide; and now the only Doubt remains whether he will come or no.

sp.speaker: Scentw.
sp.p: That's reſolv'd, Madam, for here's the Knight.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: And do I once more behold that lovely Object, whoſe Idea fills my Mind, and forms my pleaſing Dreams!

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: What beginning again in Heroicks!—Sir George, don't you remember how little Fruit your laſt Prodigal Oration produc'd, not one bare ſingle Word in anſwer.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Ha! the Voice of my Incognita—Why did you take Ten Thouſand ways to captivate a Heart your Eyes alone had vanquiſh'd.

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: Prithee, no more of theſe Flights; for our Time's but ſhort, and we muſt fall into Buſineſs: Do you think we can agree on that ſame terrible Bugbear, Matrimony, without heartily repenting on both ſides.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: It has been my wiſh ſince firſt my longing Eyes beheld ye.

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: And your happy Ears drank in the pleaſing News, I had Thirty Thouſand Pound.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Unkind! Did I not offer you in thoſe purchas'd Minutes to run the riſque of your Fortune, ſo you wou'd but ſecure that lovely Perſon to my Arms.

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: Well, if you have ſuch Love and Tenderneſs, (ſince our Woing has been ſhort) pray reſerve it for our future Days, to let the World ſee we are Lovers after Wedlock; twill be a Novelty—

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Haſte then, and let us tye the Knot, and prove the envy'd Pair—

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: Hold! not ſo faſt; I have provided better than to venture on dangerous Experiments headlong—My Guardian, truſting to my diſſembled Love, has given up my Fortune to my own diſpoſe; but with this Proviſo, that he to Morrow Morning weds me. He is now gone to Doctors-Commons for a Licenſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Ha, a Licenſe!

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p:
But I have planted Emiſſaries that infallibly take him down to Epſom, under pretence that a Brother Uſurer of
his is to make him his Executor; the thing on Earth he covets.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: 'Tis his known Character.

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: Now my Inſtruments confirm him this Man is dying, and he ſends me word he goes this Minute; it muſt be to Morrow e'er he can be undeceiv'd. That time is ours.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Let us improve it then, and ſettle on our coming Years, endleſs, endleſs Happineſs.

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: I dare not ſtir till I hear he's on the Road—then I and my Writings, the moſt material point, are ſoon remov'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: I have one Favour to aſk, if it lies in your power, you wou'd be a Friend to poor Charles, tho' the Son of this tenacious Man: He is as free from all his Vices, as Nature and a good Education can make him; and what now I have Vanity enough to hope will induce you, he is the Man on Earth I love.

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: I never was his Enemy, and only put it on as it help'd my Deſigns on his Father. If his Uncle's Eſtate ought to be in his Poſſeſſion, which I ſhrewdly ſuſpect, I may do him a ſingular piece of Service.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: You are all Goodneſs.

sp.speaker: Scentw.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, my Maſter and Mr. Marplot are juſt coming into the Houſe.

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: Undone, undone! if he finds you here in this Criſis, all my Plots are unravell'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: What ſhall I do! can't I get back into the Garden?

sp.speaker: Scentw.
sp.p: Oh, no! he comes up thoſe Stairs.

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: Here, here, here! can you condeſcend to ſtand behind this Chimney-Board, Sir George?

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Any where, any where, dear Madam, without Ceremony.

sp.speaker: Scentw.
sp.p: Come, come, Sir; lie cloſe—

div.stage: Enter Sir Francis and Marplot: Sir Francis peeling an Orange.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: I cou'd not go, tho' 'tis upon Life and Death, without taking leave of dear Chargee. Beſides this Fellow buz'd in my Ears, that thou might'ſt be ſo deſperate to ſhoot that wild Rake which haunts the Garden-Gate; and that wou'd bring us into trouble, dear—

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: So, Marplot brought you back then: I am oblig'd to him for that, I'm ſure— (Frowning at Marplot aſide.

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: By her Looks ſhe means ſhe is not oblig'd to me. I have done ſome Miſchief now, but what I can't imagine.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Well, Chargee, I have had three Meſſengers to come to Epſom to my Neighbour Squeezum's, who, for all his vaſt Riches, is departing. (Sighs.

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: Ay, ſee what all you Uſurers muſt come to.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Peace, ye young Knave! Some Forty Years hence I may think on't—But, Chargee, I'll be with thee to Morrow, before thoſe pretty Eyes are open; I will, I will, Chargee, I'll rouze you, I faith.—Here Mrs. Scentwell, lift up your Lady's Chimney-Board, that I may throw my Peel in, and not litter her Chamber.

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: Oh my Stars! what will become of us now?

sp.speaker: Scentw.
sp.p: Oh, pray Sir give it me; I love it above all things in Nature, indeed I do.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: No, no, Huſſy; you have the Green Pip already, I'll have no more Apothecary's Bills. (Goes towards the Chimney.

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: Hold, hold, hold, dear Gardee, I have a, a, a, a, a Monkey ſhut up there; and if you open it before the Man comes that is to tame it, 'tis ſo wild 'twill break all my China, or get away, and that wou'd break my Heart; for I am fond on't to diſtraction, next thee dear Gardee. In a flattering Tone.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Well, well, Chargee, I won't open it; ſhe ſhall have her Monkey, poor Rogue; here throw this Peel out of the Window.

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p:
A Monkey, dear Madam, let me ſee it; I can tame
a Monkey as well as the beſt of them all. Oh how I love the little Miniatures of Man.

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: Be quiet, Miſchief, and ſtand farther from the Chimney—You ſhall not ſee my Monkey—why ſure— (Striving with him.

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: For Heaven's ſake, dear, Madam, let me but peep, to ſee if it be as pretty as my Lady Fiddle-Faddle's. Has it got a Chain?

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: Not yet, but I deſign it one ſhall laſt its Life-time: Nay, you ſhall not ſee it—Look, Gardee, how he teazes me!

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: (Getting between him and the Chimney.) Sirrah, Sirrah, let my Chargee's Monkey alone, or Bambo ſhall fly about your Ears, What is there no dealing with you?

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: Pugh, pox of the Monkey! here's a Rout: I wiſh he may Rival you.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, they put two more Horſes in the Coach, as you order'd, and 'tis ready at the Door.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Well, I am going to be Executor, better for thee, Jewel. B'ye Chargee, one buſs!—I'm glad thou haſt got a Monkey to divert thee a little.

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: Thank'e, dear Gardee.—Nay, I'll ſee you to the Coach.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: That's kind, adod.

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: Come along, Impertinence. (To Marplot.

sp.speaker: Marpl
sp.p: (Stepping back.) Egad, I will ſee the Monkey now. (Lifts up the Board, and diſcovers Sir George.) Oh Lord, Oh Lord! Thieves, Thieves, Murder!

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Dam'e, you unlucky Dog! 'tis I, which way ſhall I get out, ſhew me inſtantly, or I'll cut your Throat.

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: Undone, undone! At that Door there. But hold, hold, break that China, and I'll bring you off. (He runs off at the Corner, and throws down ſome China.

div.stage: Re-enter Sir Francis, Miranda, and Scentwell.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Mercy on me! what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: Oh you Toad! what have you done?

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: No great harm, I beg of you to forgive me: Longing to ſee the Monkey, I did but juſt ràiſe up the Board, and it flew over my Shoulders, ſcratch'd all my Face, broke yon' China, and whiſk'd out of the Window.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Was ever ſuch an unlucky Rogue! Sirrah, I forbid you my Houſe. Call the Servants to get the Monkey again; I wou'd ſtay my ſelf to look it, but that you know my earneſt Buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Scentw.
sp.p: Oh my Lady will be the beſt to lure it back; all them Creatures love my Lady extremely.

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: Go, go, dear Gardee; I hope I ſhall recover it.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: B'ye, b'ye, Dear'e. Ah, Miſchief, how you look now! B'ye, b'ye.

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: Scentwell, ſee him in the Coach, and bring me word.

sp.speaker: Scentw.
sp.p: Yes, Madam,

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: So, Sir, you have done your Friend a ſignal piece of Service, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: Why look you, Madam! if I have committed a fault, thank your ſelf; no Man is more Serviceable when I am let into a Secret, nor none more unlucky at finding it out. Who cou'd divine your Meaning, when you talk'd of a Blunderbuſs, who thought of a Rendevous? and when you talk'd of a Monkey, who the Devil dreamt of Sir George?

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: A ſign you converſe but little with our Sex, when you can't reconcile Contradictions.

sp.speaker: Scentw.
sp.p: He's gone, Madam, as faſt as the Coach and Six can carry him.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Then I may appear.

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: Dear, Sir George, make my Peace! On my Soul, I did not think of you.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: I dare ſwear thou didſt not. Madam, I beg you to forgive him.

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: Well, Sir George, if he can be ſecret.

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: Ods heart, Madam, I'm as ſecret as a Prieſt when I'm truſted.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Why 'tis with a Prieſt our Buſineſs is at preſent.

sp.speaker: Scentw.
sp.p: Madam, here's Mrs. Iſabinda's Woman to wait on you.

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: Bring her up,
How do'e Mrs. Patch, what News from your Lady?

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: That's for your private Ear, Madam. Sir George, there's a Friend of yours has an urgent Occaſion for your Aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: His Name.

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: Ha! then there is ſomething a-foot that I know nothing of. I'll wait on you, Sir George.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: A third Perſon may not be proper perhaps; as ſoon as I have diſpatch'd my own Affairs, I am at his Service. I'll ſend my Servant to tell him, I'll wait upon him in half an Hour.

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: How come you employ'd in this Meſſage, Mrs. Patch?

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: Want of Buſineſs, Madam. I am diſcharg'd by my Maſter, but hope to ſerve my Lady ſtill.

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: How! Diſcharg'd! you muſt tell me the whole Story within.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: With all my Heart, Madam.

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: Piſh! Pox, I wiſh I were fairly out of they Houſe. I find Marriage is the end of this Secret: And now I am half mad to know what Charles wants him for. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Madam, I'm doubly preſs'd, by Love and Friendſhip: This Exigence admits of no delay. Shall we make Marplot of the Party?

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: If you'll run the Hazard, Sir George; I believe he means well.

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: Nay, nay, for my part, I deſire to be let into nothing: I'll be gone, therefore pray don't miſtruſt me. (Going.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p:
So now has he a mind to be gone to Charles: But not knowing what Affairs he may have upon his Hands at
preſent, I'm reſolv'd he ſhan't ſtir: No, Mr. Marplot, you muſt not leave us, we want a third Perſon. (Takes hold of him.

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: I never had more mind to be gone in my Life.

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: Come along then; if we fail in the Voyage, thank your ſelf for taking this ill ſtarr'd Gentleman on Board.

l.hi: That Veſſel ne'er can Unſucceſsful prove,
Whoſe Freight is Beauty, and whoſe Pilot Love.

div.trailer: The End of the Fourth ACT.

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: WELL, Patch, I have done a ſtrange bold thing! my Fate is determin'd, and Expectation is no more. Now to avoid the Impertinence and Roguery of an old Man, I have thrown myſelf into the Extravagance of a young one; if he ſhould deſpiſe, ſlight or uſe me ill, there's no Remedy from a Huſband, but the Grave; and that's a terrible Sanctuary to one of my Age and Conſtitution.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: O fear not, Madam, you'll find your Account in Sir George Airy; it is impoſſible a Man of Senſe ſhou'd uſe a Woman ill, indued with Beauty, Wit and Fortune. It muſt be the Lady's fault, if ſhe does not wear the unfaſhionable Name of Wife eaſie, when nothing but Complaiſance and good Humour is requiſite on either ſide to make them happy.

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: I long till I am out of this Houſe, leſt any Accident ſhou'd bring my Guardian back. Scentwell, put my beſt Jewels into the little Caſket, ſlip them into thy Pocket, and let us march off to Sir Jealous's.

sp.speaker: Scentw.
sp.p: It ſhall be done, Madam.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: Sir George will be impatient, Madam; if their Plot ſucceeds, we ſhall be well receiv'd; if not, he will be able to protect us. Beſides, I long to know how my young Lady fares.

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: Farewel, old Mammon, and thy deteſted Walls; 'twill be no more ſweet Sir Francis, I ſhall be compell'd to the odious Taſk of Diſſembling no longer to get my own, and coax him with the wheedling Names of my Precious, my Dear, dear Gardee. O Heavens!

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Ah, my ſweet Chargee, don't be frighted. (She ſtarts.) But thy poor Gardee has been abus'd, cheated, fool'd, betray'd, but no body knows by whom.

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: (Aſide.) Undone! paſt Redemption.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: What won't you ſpeak to me, Chargee!

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: I'm ſo ſurpriz'd with Joy to ſee you, I know not what to ſay.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Poor, dear Girl! But do'e know that my Son, or ſome ſuch Rogue, to rob or murder me, or borh, contriv'd this Journey? For upon the Road I met my Neighbour Squeſezum well, and coming to Town.

sp.speaker: Miran,
sp.p: Good lack, good lack! what Tricks are there in this World!

div.stage: Enter Scentwell, with a Diamond Necklace in her Hand; not ſeeing Sir Francis.

sp.speaker: Scentw.
sp.p: Madam be pleas'd to tye this Neck-lace on, for I can't get it into the— (Seeing Sir Francis.

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: The Wench is a Fool, I think! cou'd you not have carried it to be mended, without putting it in the Box?

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: Only Dear'e, I bid her, I bid her—Your ill Uſage has put every thing out of my Head. But won't you go, Gardee, and find out theſe Fellows, and have them puniſh'd! and, and—

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Where ſhou'd I look them, Child? No I'll ſit me down contented with my Safety, nor ſtir out of my own Doors, till I go with thee to a Parſon.

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: (Aſide.) If he goes into his Cloſet I am ruin'd. Oh! bleſs me in this Fright, I had forgot Mrs. Patch.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: Ay, Madam, and I ſtay for your ſpeedy Anſwer.

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: (Aſide.) I muſt get him out of the Houſe. Now aſſiſt me, Fortune.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Mrs. Patch, I profeſs I did not ſee you: How doſt thou do, Mrs. Patch? Well, don't you repent leaving my Chargee?

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: Yes, every body muſt love her—but I came now—Madam, What did I come for? My Invention is at the laſt Ebb. (Aſide to Miranda.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Nay, never whiſper, tell me.

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: She came, dear Gardee to invite me to her Lady's Wedding, and you ſhall go with me Gardee, 'tis to be done this Moment to, a Spaniſh Merchant; Old Sir Jealous keeps on his Humour, the firſt Minute he ſees her, the next he marries her.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, I'd go if I thought the ſight of Matrimony wou'd tempt Chargee to perform her Promiſe: There was a ſmile, there was a conſenting Look with thoſe pretty Twinklers, worth a Million. Ods precious, I am happier than the Great Mogul, the Emperor of China, or all the Potentates that are not in Wars. Speak, confirm it, make me leap out of my Skin.

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: When one has reſolv'd, 'tis in vain to ſtand ſhall I, ſhall I; if ever I marry, poſitively this is my Wedding Day.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Oh! happy, happy Man—Verily I will beget a Son, the firſt Night ſhall diſinherit that Dog Charles. I have Eſtate enough to purchaſe a Barony, and be the immortalizing the whole Family of the Gripes.

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: Come then Gardee, give me thy Hand, let's to this Houſe of Hymen.

p.hi: My Choice is fix'd, let good or ill betide,

div.stage: Enter Sir Jealous meeting a Servant.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, here's a couple of Gentlemen enquire for you; one of them calls himſelf Seignior Diego Babinetto.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Ha! Seignior Babinetto! Admit 'em inſtantly—Joyful Minute; I'll have my Daughter marry'd to Night.

div.stage: Enter Charles in Spaniſh Habit, with Sir George dreſt like a Merchant.

p.hi: Senior, beſo Las Manos vueſtra merced es muy bien venido en eſta tierra.

Senhor, ſoy muy humilde, y muy obligado Cryado de vueſtra merced: Mi Padre Embia a vueſtra merced, los mas profondos de ſus reſpetos; y a Commiſſionado eſte Mercadel Ingles, de concluyr un negocio, que me Haze el mas dichoſo hombre del mundo, Haziendo me ſu yerno.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: I am glad on't, for I find I have loſt much of my Spaniſh. Sir, I am your moſt humble Servant. Seignior Don Diego Babinetto has informed me that you are commiſſion'd by Seignior Don Pedro, &c. his worthy Father.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: To ſee an Affair of Marriage conſummated between a Daughter of yours, and Seignior Diego Babinetto his Son here. True, Sir, ſuch a Truſt is repos'd in me as that Letter will inform you. I hope 'twill paſs upon him. (Aſide.) (Gives him a Letter.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Ay, 'tis his Hand. (Seems to read.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Good—you have counterfeited to a Nicety, Charles. (Aſide to Charles.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: If the whole Plot ſucceeds as well, I'm happy.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Sir I find by this, that you are a Man of Honour and Probity; I think, Sir, he calls you Meanwell.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Meanwell is my Name, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: A very good Name, and very ſignificant.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Yes Faith, if he knew all. (Aſide

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: For to Mean-well is to be honeſt, and to be honeſt is the Virtue of a Friend, and a Friend is the Delight and Support of Human Society.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: You ſhall find that I'll diſcharge the part of a Friend in what I have undertaken, Sir Jealous.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: But little does he think to whom. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Therefore, Sir, I muſt intreat the Preſence of your fair Daughter, and the Aſſiſtance of your Chaplain; for Seignor Don Pedro ſtrictly enjoyn'd me to ſee the Marriage Rites perform'd as ſoon as we ſhould arrive, to avoid the Accidental Overtures of Venus.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Overtures of Venus.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, that is, thoſe little Hawking Females that traverſe the Park, and the Play-houſe to put off their damag'd Ware—they faſten upon Foreigners like Leeches, and watch their Arrival as carefully, as the Kentiſh Men do a Ship-wreck. I warrant you they have heard of him already.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Nay, I know this Town ſwarms with them.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Ay, and then you know the Spaniards are naturally Amorous, but very Conſtant, the firſt Face fixes 'em, and it may be dangerous to let him ramble e'er he is tied.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Well hinted. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Pat to my Purpoſe—Well, Sir, there is but one thing more, and they ſhall be married inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Pray Heaven, that one thing more don't ſpoil all. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Don Pedro writ me Word in his laſt but one, that he deſign'd the Sum of Five Thouſand Crowns by way of Joynture for my Daughter; and that it ſhou'd be paid into my Hand upon the Day of Marriage.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Oh! the Devil. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: In order to lodge it in ſome of our Funds, in caſe ſhe ſhould become a Widow, and return for England.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Pox on't, this is an unlucky Turn. What ſhall I ſay? (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: And he does not mention one Word of it in this Letter.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: I don't know how he ſhould.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Humph! True, Sir Jealous, he told me ſuch a Thing, but, but, but, but—he, he, he, he—he did not imagine that you wou'd inſiſt upon the very Day, for, for, for, for Money you know is dangerous returning by Sea, an, an, an, an—

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Zounds, ſay we have brought it in Commodities. (Aſide to Sir George.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: And ſo Sir, he has ſent it in Merchandize, Tobacco, Sugars, Spices, Limons, and ſo forth, which ſhall be turn'd into Money with all Expedition: In the mean time, Sir, if you pleaſe to accept of my Bond for Performance.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: It is enough, Sir, I am ſo pleas'd with the Countenance of Seignior Diego, and the Harmony of your Name, that I'll take your Word, and will fetch my Daughter this Moment. Within there (Enter Servant) deſire Mr. Tackum my Neighbour's Chaplain to walk hither.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I'll return in an Inſtant.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Wondrous well. Let me embrace thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Egad that 5000 l. had like to have ruin'd the Plot.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: But that's over! And if Fortune throws no more Rubs in our way.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Thou'lt carry the Prize—but hiſt, here he comes.

div.stage: Enter Sir Jealous, dragging in Iſabinda.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Come along, you ſtubborn Baggage you, come along.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Oh hear me, Sir! hear me but ſpeak one Word,
Do not deſtroy my everlaſting Peace;
My Soul abhors this Spaniard you have choſe,
Nor can I wed him without being curſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: How's that!

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Let this Poſture move your tender Nature. (Kneels.
For ever will I hang upon theſe Knees;
Nor looſe my Hands till you cut off my hold,
If you refuſe to hear me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Oh! that I cou'd diſcover my ſelf to her. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Have a care what you do. You had better truſt to his Obſtinacy, (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Did you ever ſee ſuch a perverſe Slut, Off I ſay. Mr. Meanwell pray help me a little.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Riſe, Madam, and do not diſoblige your Father, who has provided a Huſband worthy of you, one that will Love you equal with his Soul, and one that you will Love, when once you know him.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Oh! never, never. Cou'd I ſuſpect that Falſhood in my Heart, I wou'd this Moment tear it from my Breaſt, and ſtreight preſent him with the Treacherous Part.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Oh! my charming faithful Dear. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Falſhood! why, who the Devil are you in Love with? Ha! Don't provoke me, for by St. Jago I ſhall beat you, Houſewife.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Heaven forbid; for I ſhall infallibly diſcover my ſelf if he ſhould. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Have Patience, Madam! and look at him: Why will you prepoſſeſs your ſelf againſt a Man that is Maſter of all the Charms you wou'd deſire in a Huſband?

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Ay, look at him, Iſabinda, Senior paſe vind adelante.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: My Heart bleeds to ſee her grieve, whom I imagin'd would with Joy receive me. Senior a obligue me vueſtra merced de ſumano.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: (Pulling up her Head.) Hold up your Head, hold up your Head, Houſewife, and look at him: Is there a properer, handſomer, better ſhap'd Fellow in England, ye Jade you? Ha! ſee, ſee the obſtinate Baggage ſhuts her Eyes; by St. Jago, I have a good mind to beat 'em out. (Puſhes her down.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Do then, Sir, kill me, kill me inſtantly.
'Tis much the kinder Action of the Two,
For 'twill be worſe than Death to wed him.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Sir Jealous, you are too paſſionate. Give me leave, I'll try by gentle Words to work her to your Purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: I pray do, Mr. Meanwell, I pray do; ſhe'll break my Heart. (Weeps) There is in that, Jewels of the Value of 3000 l. which were her Mother's; and a Paper wherein I have ſettled one half of my Eſtate upon her now, and the whole when I dye. But provided ſhe marries this Gentleman, elſe by St. Jago, I'll turn her out of Doors to beg or ſtarve. Tell her this, Mr. Meanwell, pray do. (Walks off.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Ha! this is beyond Expectation—Truſt to me, Sir, I'll lay the dangerous Conſequence of diſobeying you at this Juncture before her, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: A ſudden Joy runs thro' my Heart like a propitious Omen. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Come, Madam, do not blindly caſt your Life away juſt in the Moment you would wiſh to ſave it.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Pray ceaſe your Trouble, Sir, I have no wiſh but ſudden Death to free me from this hated Spaniard. If you are his Friend inform him what I ſay; my Heart is given to another Youth, whom I love with the ſame ſtrength of Paſſion that I hate this Diego; with whom, if I am forc'd to wed, my own Hand ſhall cut the Gordian Knot.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Suppoſe this Spaniard which you ſtrive to ſhun ſhould be the very Man to whom you'd flye?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Would you not blame your raſh Reſult, and curſe thoſe Eyes that would not look on Charles.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: On Charles! Oh you have inſpir'd new Life, and collected every wandring Senſe. Where is he? Oh! let me flye into his Arms (Riſes.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Hold, hold, hold, S'Death, Madam, you'll ruin all, your Father believes him to be Seignor Barbinetto. Compoſe your ſelf a little, pray Madam. (He runs to Sir Jealous.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Her Eyes declare ſhe knows me. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: She begins to hear Reaſon, Sir, the fear of being turn'd out of Doors has done it. (Runs back to Iſabinda.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: 'Tis he, oh! my raviſh'd Soul.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Take heed, Madam, you don't betray your ſelf. Seem with Reluctance to conſent, or you are undone, (runs to Sir Jealous) ſpeak gently to her, Sir, I'm ſure ſhe'll yield, I ſee it in her Face.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p:
Well, Iſabinda, can you refuſe to bleſs a Father, whoſe only Care is to make you happy, as Mr. Meanwell has inform'd you. Come, wipe thy Eyes; nay, prithee do, or thou wilt break thy Father's Heart; ſee thou bring'ſt the
Tears in mine to think of thy undutiful Carriage to me. (Weeps.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Oh! do not weep, Sir, your Tears are like a Ponyard to my Soul; do with me what you pleaſe, I am all Obedience.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Ha! then thou art my Child agen.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: 'Tis done, and now Friend the Day's thy own.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: The happieſt of my Life, if nothing Intervene.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: And wilt thou love him?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I will endeavour it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, Here is Mr. Tackum

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Shew him into the Parlour—Senior tome vind ſueipora; cete Momento les Juntta les Manos. (Gives her to Charles.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Oh! tranſport—Senior yo la recibo Como ſe deve un Teforo tan Grande. Oh! my Joy, my Life, my Soul. (Embrace.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: My Faithful everlaſting Comfort.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal,
sp.p: Now, Mr. Meanwell let's to the Parſon,

l.hi: Who, by his Art will join this Pair for Life,
Make me the happieſt Father, her the happieſt Wife.

head.hi: SCENE Changes to the Street before Sir Jealous's Door.

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: I have hunted all over the Town ſor Charles, but can't find him; and by Whiſper's ſcouting at the End of the Street, I ſuſpect he muſt be in the Houſe again. I'm inform'd too that he has borrow'd a Spaniſh Habit out of the Playhouſe: What can it mean?
sp.stage: Enter a Servant of Sir Jealous's to him, out of the Houſe.
sp.p: Hark'e, Sir, do you belong to this Houſe?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: Pray can you tell if there be a Gentleman in it in Spaniſh Habit?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: There is a Spaniſh Gentleman within, that is juſt a going to marry my young Lady, Sir.

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: Are you ſure he is a Spaniſh Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Serv,
sp.p: I'm ſure he ſpeaks no Engliſh, that I hear of.

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: Then that can't be him I want; for 'tis an Engliſh Gentleman, tho' I ſuppoſe he may be dreſs'd like a Spaniard, that I enquire after.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Ha! who knows but this may be an Impoſtor? I'll inform my Maſter; for if he ſhou'd be impos'd upon, he'll beat us all round, (Aſide.) Pray, come in, Sir, and ſee if this be the Perſon you enquire for.

head.hi: SCENE Changes to the Inſide of the Houſe.

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: So, this was a good Contrivance: If this be Charles, now will he wonder how I found him out.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: What is your earneſt Buſineſs, Blockhead, that you muſt ſpeak with me before the Ceremony's paſt? Ha! who's this?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Why this Gentleman, Sir, wants another Gentleman in Spaniſh Habit, he ſays.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: In Spaniſh Habit! 'tis ſome Friend of Seignior Don Diego's, I warrant. Sir, I ſuppoſe you wou'd ſpeak with Seignior Barbinetto—

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: Hy-day! what the Devil does he ſay now!—Sir, I don't underſtand you.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Don't you underſtand Spaniſh, Sir?

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: Not I indeed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: I thought you had known Seignior Barbinetto.

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: Not I, upon my word, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: What then you'd ſpeak with his Friend, the Engliſh Merchant, Mr. Meanwell.

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: Neither, Sir; not I.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Why who are you then, Sir? And what do you want? (In an angry Tone.

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: Nay, nothing at all, not I, Sir. Pox on him! I wiſh I were out, he begins to exalt his Voice, I ſhall be beaten agen.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Nothing at all, Sir! Why then what Buſineſs have you in my Houſe? ha?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: You ſaid you wanted a Gentleman in Spaniſh Habit.

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: Why, ay, but his Name is neither Barbinetto nor Meanwell.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: What is his Name then, Sirrah, ha? Now I look at you agen, I believe you are the Rogue threatned me with half a Dozen Mirmidons—Speak, Sir, who is it you look for? or, or—

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: A terrible old Dog!—Why, Sir, only an honeſt young Fellow of my Acquaintance—I thought that here might be a Ball, and that he might have been here in a Maſquerade; 'tis Charles, Sir Francis Gripe's Son, becauſe I know he us'd to come hither ſometimes.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Did he ſo?—Not that I know of, I'm ſure. Pray Heaven that this be Don Diego—If I ſhou'd be trick'd now—Ha! my Heart miſgives me plaguily—within there! ſtop the Marriage—Run, Sirrah, call all my Servants! I'll be ſatiſfy'd that this is Seignior Pedro's Son e'er he has my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: Ha, Sir George, what have I done now?

div.stage: Enter Sir George with a drawn Sword between the Scenes.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Ha! Marplot, here—Oh the unlucky Dog—what's the matter, Sir Jealous?

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Nay, I don't know the matter, Mr. Meanwell.

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: Upon my Soul, Sir George— (Going up to Sir Geo.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Nay then, I'm betray'd, ruin'd, undone: Thieves, Traytors, Rogues! (Offers to go in.) Stop the Marriage, I ſay—

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: I ſay, go on Mr. Tackum—Nay, no Ent'ring here, I guard this Paſſage, old Gentleman; the Act and Deed were both your own, and I'll ſee 'em ſign'd, or die for't.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: A pox on the Act and Deed!—Fall on, knock him down.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Ay, come on, Scoundrils! I'll prick your Jackets for you.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: 'Zounds, Sirrah, I'll be reveng'd on you. (Beats Marplot.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Ay, there your Vengeance is due; Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: Why what do you beat me for? I han't marry'd your Daughter.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Raſcals! why don't you knock him down?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: We are afraid of his Sword, Sir; if you'll take that from him, we'll knock him down preſently.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Seize her then.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Raſcals, retire; ſhe's my Wife, touch her if you dare, I'll make Dogs meat of you.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Ah! downright Engliſh:—Oh, oh, oh, oh!

div.stage: Enter Sir Francis Gripe, Miranda, Patch, Scentwell, and Whiſper.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Into the Houſe of Joy we enter without knocking: Ha! I think 'tis the Houſe of Sorrow, Sir Jealous.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Oh Sir Francis! are you come? What was this your Contrivance, to abuſe, trick, and chouſe me of my Child!

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: My Contrivance! what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: No, you don't know your Son there in Spaniſh Habit.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: How! my Son in Spaniſh Habit. Sirrah, you'll come to be hang'd; get out of my ſight, ye Dog! get out of my ſight.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Get out of your ſight, Sir! Get out with your Bags; let's ſee what you'll give him now to maintain my Daughter on.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Give him! He ſhall be never the better for a Penny of mine—and you might have look'd after your Daughter better, Sir Jealous. Trick'd, quotha! Egad, I think you deſign'd to trick me: But look ye, Gentlemen, I believe I ſhall trick you both. This Lady is my Wife, do you ſee? And my Eſtate ſhall deſcend only to the Heirs of her Body.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Lawfully begotten by me—I ſhall be extremely oblig'd to you, Sir Francis.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, poor Sir George! You ſee your Project was of no uſe. Does not your Hundred Pound ſtick in your Stomach? Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: No faith, Sir Francis, this Lady has given me a Cordial for that. (Takes her by the Hand.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, you have nothing to ſay to this Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Nor you nothing to do with my Wife, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Wife, Sir!

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: Ay really, Guardian, 'tis even ſo. I hope you'll forgive my firſt Offence.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: What have you chous'd me out of my Conſent, and your Writings then, Miſtreſs, ha?

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: Out of nothing but my own, Guardian.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, 'tis ſome Comfort at leaſt to ſee you are over-reach'd as well as my ſelf. Will you ſettle your Eſtate upon your Son now?

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: He ſhall ſtarve firſt.

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: That I have taken care to prevent. There, Sir, is the Writings of your Uncle's Eſtate, which has been your due theſe three Years. (Gives Char. Papers.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: I ſhall ſtudy to deſerve this Favour.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: What have you robb'd me too, Miſtreſs! Egad I'll make you reſtore 'em.—Huſwife, I will ſo.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Take care I don't make you pay the Arrears, Sir. 'Tis well its no worſe, ſince 'tis no better. Come, young Man, ſeeing thou haſt out-witted me, take her, and Bleſs you both.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, you'll beſtow your Bleſſing too, 'tis all I'll aſk. (Kneels.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Confound you all!

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: Mercy upon us! how he looks! (Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ne'er mind his Curſes, Charles; thou'lt thrive not one jot the worſe for 'em. Since this Gentleman is reconcil'd, we are all made happy.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: I always lov'd Precaution, and took care to avoid Dangers. But when a thing was paſt, I ever had Philoſophy to be eaſie.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Which is the true ſign of a great Soul: I lov'd your Daughter, and ſhe me, and you ſhall have no reaſon to repent her Choice.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: You will not blame me, Sir, ſor loving my own Country beſt.

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: So here's every body happy, I find, but poor Pilgarlick. I wonder what Satisfaction I ſhall have, for being cuff'd, kick'd, and beaten in your Service.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: I have been a little too familiar with you, as things are fallen out; but ſince there's no help for't, you muſt forgive me.

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: Egad I think ſo—But provided that you be not ſo familiar for the future.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Thou haſt been an unlucky Rogue.

sp.speaker: Marp.
sp.p: But very honeſt.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: That I'll vouch for; and freely forgive thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: And I'll do you one piece of Service more, Marplot, I'll take care that Sir Francis make you Maſter of your Eſtate.

sp.speaker: Marpl.
sp.p: That will make me as happy as any of you.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: Your humble Servant begs leave to remind you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Sir, I hope you'll give me leave to take Patch into favour again.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Nay, let your Huſband look to that, I have done with my Care.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Her own Liberty ſhall always oblige me. Here's no Body but honeſt Whiſper and Mrs. Scentwell to be provided for now. It ſhall be left to their Choice to Marry, or keep their Services.

sp.speaker: Whiſp.
sp.p: Nay then, I'll ſtick to my Maſter.

sp.speaker: Scentw.
sp.p: Coxcomb! and I prefer my Lady before a Footman.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Hark, I hear Muſick, the Fidlers ſmell a Wedding. What ſay you young Fellows, will ye have a Dance?

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: With all my Heart; call 'em in.

sp.speaker: Sir Jeal.
sp.p: Now let us in and refreſh our ſelves with a chearful Glaſs, in which we'll bury all Animoſities: And

l.hi: By my Example let all Parents move,
And never ſtrive to croſs their Childrens Love;
But ſtill ſubmit that Care to Providence above.
